channel.title: BBC News - Home

item.title: Covid-19: Pubs could require vaccine passports - Boris Johnson
item.description: But one Conservative MP says "papers for pubs" would lead the country into "a ghastly trap".

item.title: Covid-19: Merkel defends rollout as vaccine pressure grows
item.description: German Chancellor Angela Merkel defends the EU's decision to procure coronavirus vaccines jointly.

item.title: Covid-19: Over-50s urged to book jabs before vaccine supplies dip
item.description: The NHS highlights the deadline of 29 March ahead of an expected slowdown in vaccine supplies in April.

item.title: Suez Canal: Owner of cargo ship blocking waterway apologises
item.description: Japanese firm Shoei Kisen Kaisha says dislodging the Ever Given is proving "extremely difficult".

item.title: Santander to close more than 100 branches
item.description: The bank says 840 staff will be affected by the decision although it will try to offer them roles elsewhere.

item.title: Johnny Depp refused permission to appeal libel verdict
item.description: A judge rules the US actor's appeal against a High Court ruling has "no real prospect of success".

item.title: Covid vaccine: AstraZeneca updates US vaccine efficacy results
item.description: The vaccine-maker slightly amends its efficacy rates as it awaits US regulatory approval.

item.title: New Alan Turing £50 note design is revealed
item.description: The banknote will enter circulation on 23 June - Alan Turing's birthday - and will be made of polymer.

item.title: Cornwall plane crash: Two pilots eject from Royal Navy jet
item.description: Two pilots are being checked for injuries after ejecting from the plane near RNAS Culdrose.

item.title: MPs to vote on extending emergency Covid powers to autumn
item.description: MPs are being asked to extend unprecedented emergency laws brought in a year ago to deal with the virus.

item.title: Nationwide tells 13,000 staff to 'work anywhere'
item.description: The UK's biggest building society says it wants to give employees more control over their lives.

item.title: Catalytic converter thefts: Surge in cases reported to Met Police
item.description: More than 300 officers took part in raids across east London, Kent and Essex, with three men arrested.

item.title: Why cutting down trees can be good for the climate
item.description: Tree felling is helping to restore an ancient ecosystem which can store even more carbon than trees do.

item.title: Coronavirus: Locked down with Mum and Dad
item.description: Many young people returned to live with their parents during the pandenic. How's it going, a year on?

item.title: Winston Churchill, Kermit and Janet Jackson recordings preserved for posterity
item.description: Their recordings are being added to the US National Recording Registry by the Library of Congress.

item.title: Lord Howe Island: Saving an Australian paradise's 'cloud forest'
item.description: A rare environment on Australia's Lord Howe Island has faced a complex battle for survival.

item.title: 'I can't see myself going back to a five-day week'
item.description: We've all got used to working flexibly so employers will need to adapt, say campaigners.

item.title: The Papers: 'No jab no pint' and EU vaccine 'peace deal' with UK
item.description: Thursday's papers look at the prospect of pub goers needing proof of a Covid vaccination to gain entry.

item.title: Covid: Nursing in pandemic 'like working in a war'
item.description: Nurses in one of England's worst-hit areas relive the year-long ordeal of caring for Covid patients.

item.title: KSI: 'I was struggling to sell tickets to gigs in 2019'
item.description: Newsbeat speaks to one of YouTube's biggest stars about what's next after selling out his 2021 tour.

item.title: Nagorno-Karabakh: The mystery of the missing church
item.description: The BBC investigates the disappearance of an Armenian church that changed hands in the recent Nagorno-Karabakh war.

item.title: What can Joe Biden really change at the border?
item.description: An increase in migrants is testing the new administration's promises on immigration.

item.title: In pictures: Container ship blocks Egypt's Suez Canal
item.description: One of the world's key shipping routes has been blocked after a huge ship ran aground.

item.title: Covid: The London bus trip that saved maybe a million lives
item.description: A conversation on a bus led to the setting up of the Recovery trial, leading to treatments for Covid.

item.title: Holyrood election 2021: The intense battle for every vote in Scotland
item.description: Polling expert Professor John Curtice looks at the issues that will decide the Scottish Parliament election on 6 May.

item.title: 'My father, the killer'
item.description: Some of the children of men who helped to "disappear" thousands of Argentines in the 1970s and 80s are now speaking out - against their fathers.

item.title: Tate McRae's journey from ballet school to pop stardom
item.description: You Broke Me First was one of 2020's biggest break-out hits, but Tate McRae never intended to be a pop star.

item.title: Scotland election 2021: Who should I vote for? Compare party policies
item.description: Compare where the parties stand on key issues - from Covid-19 and the NHS to education and the environment.

item.title: 'I have learned how to survive with a bow and arrow'
item.description: The Covid pandemic and last summer's social unrest has inspired more Americans to take up hunting.

item.title: Fifa to take no action over Norway players' Qatar human rights protest
item.description: Norway players wear T-shirts bearing the message 'Human rights on and off the pitch' before their 2022 World Cup qualifier against Gibraltar to show support for Qatar migrant workers.

item.title: England v San Marino: How do you improve world's worst national team?
item.description: They are bottom of the Fifa rankings, but San Marino drew their last two Nations League games. This is how the world's worst national team are getting (a bit) better.

item.title: 'Jules has Skype calls with Chris Gayle' - Married At First Sight's Cam Merchant on his life in cricket
item.description: Married At First Sight star Cam Merchant on his former life as a professional cricketer, visiting Sachin Tendulkar's house and Christmas with Chris Gayle.

item.title: Former England fly-half Cipriani agrees contract with Bath
item.description: Former England fly-half Danny Cipriani agrees a deal to join Bath on an "extended one-year contract" that begins in May.

item.title: 'This little flame never lost hope' - Olympic torch relay finally begins
item.description: A year later than planned, an Olympic torch relay with a difference begins in Japan as the build-up for the Tokyo Games gets under way.

item.title: 'If you want to default me, I will gladly sue' - Pospisil sorry for furious rant in Miami
item.description: Vasek Pospisil apologises for an expletive-filled rant in a match at the Miami Open, during which he threatened to sue tennis organisers.

item.title: Belgium fight back to beat Wales in opening World Cup qualifier
item.description: Wales threaten to cause another upset against Belgium before eventually falling to defeat in their opening World Cup qualifier.

item.title: Will I need a vaccine passport to go to the pub or travel abroad?
item.description: A government review is considering whether people will need to prove they have been vaccinated.

item.title: Lockdown rules: What are the restrictions in your area?
item.description: Use our search tool to find out about coronavirus rules and restrictions where you live.

item.title: Covid: What’s the problem with the EU vaccine rollout?
item.description: The coronavirus vaccine is being rolled out across the EU but there have been delays.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: People aged 50 and over are urged to book their Covid vaccine in the next few days.

item.title: Covid vaccine: Side effects and why it can’t give you the virus
item.description: It's normal to experience some mild side effects, such as a headache or a raised temperature.

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Wales and Scotland have announced the easing of restrictions on people meeting

item.title: Covid: When can I go on holiday abroad or in the UK?
item.description: Anyone in England who travels abroad without good reason will soon face a £5000 fine.

item.title: Covid: How are European countries tackling the pandemic?
item.description: Are European countries relaxing restrictions put in place to control a new wave of infections?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The unemployment rate is rising as Covid hits different parts of the economy.

item.title: Covid: The inside story of the government's battle against the virus
item.description: Twenty of Downing Street's most senior politicians, officials and former officials take you "into the room" where essential Covid decisions were being made.

item.title: Covid: The countries that nailed it, and what we can learn from them
item.description: A year into the pandemic, we look at countries that have had some success in tackling the virus.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Coronavirus: Your tributes to those who have died
item.description: A collection of your tributes to some of the thousands of people in the UK who have died with coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: What is the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine?
item.description: The Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccines should save many lives, say experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid: More walking and family chats post-lockdown - poll suggests
item.description: We've done more walking and worked more from home this year, according to a BBC-commissioned poll.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as almost 28 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid-19: Have a million people left the UK?
item.description: How far has the UK's foreign-born population fallen during the coronavirus pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: When will pubs, hairdressers and gyms open?
item.description: Lockdown is being eased, so when will places like hairdressers, pubs and gyms open?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the R number and how is it calculated?
item.description: The R number is a simple but crucial figure at the heart of lockdown decisions across the UK.

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should be shielding and why?
item.description: Shielding in England will end on 31 March.

item.title: Covid-19: EU warns UK over vaccine exports
item.description: The EU threatens to block vaccine exports to the UK unless it "gets its fair share".

item.title: Coronavirus: How are the rules for weddings changing across the UK?
item.description: Wedding ceremonies are still restricted across the UK, but there are plans to ease the rules.

item.title: EU plans for a 'vaccine passport' to allow travel
item.description: 'Vaccine passport' plans have been proposed by the EU, in order to make travel easier this summer.

item.title: Covid: When will children return to school and what are the rules?
item.description: Children are returning to school across the UK, after months of enforced home-schooling.

item.title: Lockdown Learning: What educational resources are on TV, iPlayer and online?
item.description: As most pupils return to school, the BBC will continue to offer a wealth of educational material.

item.title: What are the care home rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: What are the new rules for testing and hotel quarantine?
item.description: Travellers going to and from the UK face a growing number of restrictions.

item.title: Am I eligible for the new furlough scheme?
item.description: Furlough has been extended until the end of September.

item.title: North Korea’s ‘only openly gay defector’ finds love
item.description: Jang Yeong-jin fled North Korea to escape a loveless marriage. Now he is engaged to his boyfriend.
